title: Compiled app doesn't start
body:
<!-- Please don't delete this template because we'll close your issue -->
<!-- Before creating an issue please make sure you are using the latest version of webpack. -->

# Bug report

I've been trying to understand this all day. If I specify `runtimeChunk`, and (maybe?) it gets minified my app doesn't start. If I comment out `runtimeChunk` my app starts. The sources all look okay and are loading, but the entry point doesn't exec.

**What is the current behavior?**
Blank screen after build.

**If the current behavior is a bug, please provide the steps to reproduce.**

I've been trying to isolate this but haven't yet. I'm sorry. I just wanted to get this out there hoping someone else has ideas.

**What is the expected behavior?**
the entry point should execute.

**Other relevant information:**
webpack version:  5.26.3
Node.js version: 15.12.0
Operating System: linux
Additional tools:
author: jsg2021

comments.body: Sorry, information is not enough to help you, maybe you forget to add something to your HTML file

I has same problem on rebuild on watch mode or build when not have previous build 
Problem started after upgrade to 5.26.0, in version 5.25.1 all working fine
@vadimka123 Maybe you can create example?

hey Guys, 

I'm using MacOS and also have similar issue. My teammates don't have it on linux. 

So we upgraded our webpack to the version `"webpack": "5.26.3"` and the initial build is ok but the rebuild is broken. 

Here is command 
```
webpack --progress --watch --mode development
```

when I apply some changes to the file, my webpack does rebuild automatically and I'm getting blank screen without any errors in console. 

How I fixed this issue temporary. I reverted my webpack to the version "webpack": "5.25.1" and on this version everything works well. Perhaps 5.26.0 works also fine, I just didn't check that.


webpack config looks like

title: Way to recognize when initial compilation with lazy plugin has finished.
body:
## Feature request

I have tried the new lazy compilation option and it's awesome!
I am creating a Create-React-App type of app using webpack-dev-middleware and one thing I noticed is that Webpack marks itself as ready (using `done` hook) before the entry point is compiled. This means if I cold start my app and immediately open the browser, I get an empty white page.

It would be nice to have a way to figure out when the initial compilation is done so only then we can open the browser for better DX. Does something like this in form of a hook already exist?

**What is the expected behavior?**
Webpack only changing to a ready state once the webapp can be visited

**What is motivation or use case for adding/changing the behavior?**
Better developer experience

**How should this be implemented in your opinion?**
For example using a hook, or changing when when Webpack calls the 'done' hook. The PR #12553 which could disable lazy importing for certain files also looks promising, because then maybe I could disable it for my entry files.

**Are you willing to work on this yourself?**
no
author: JonnyBurger

comments.body: I don't think you need hook here, you can do it on tool/application side
@alexander-akait Can you tell me how I could implement it on the application side?
You have `__webpack_hash__` so you can check it was changed or not

There are multiple things that you could do about that:

If your application has only a single entrypoint it make sense to disable lazy compilation for entrypoints, because there is no benefit in only compiling it when visited (since you can only visit this entrypoint). We should make this the default when there is only a single entrypoint.

Above thing will also give the the experience that the browser only opens when the page is ready.

Lazy Compilation has the option to create a custom User Interface when lazy compiling via the `experiments.lazyCompilation.client` option. This allows to disable e. g. a spinner and a message in the browser.

Hey there!

This looks very helpful! Thanks @sokra 

> We should make this the default when there is only a single entrypoint.

I was wondering if it is still your intent to do this by default. 
From my tests with `webpack@5.58.1` and the following config
```
  ...
  entry: './src/index.tsx', // single entry point
  experiments: {
    lazyCompilation: true,
  },
```
It doesn't look like `entries=false` is the default yet.

Maybe you will only do this when `lazyCompilation` is no longer experimental but I wanted to confirm so.

Thank you for your time!

title: overwrite watch config from CLI
body: I have a webpack.config.js with watch:true and I would like to overwrite that setting when I call "webpack" from the CLI in a certain environment. Is this possible? Like `webpack --watch=false` would be nice
author: flyon

comments.body: why does it need to be in your config? why not use `--watch` through a separate script?

Because we already have three scripts for dev/staging/deployment and I now
want to create nonminified bundles for staging and deployment too, so I was
hoping to re-use the dev script for that, but it has watch:true for local
development. Its totally possible to create another script, was just
looking for other options
You could provide your own argument that is read in your dev config like --no-watch and process.argv.indexOf("--no-watch") >= 0 that's read from inside the config file
ah, that's how that works! thanks, thats perfect!

title: re-bundle css + js which split by System.import
body:
``` js
System.import('1.js')
System.import('2.js')

// After `ExtractTextPlugin.extract('style')` , output:
// 1.js, 1.css, 2.js, 2.css
```

How to inline the css, get a new full-bundle like:

 `1.js` = `1.js` + `1.css`

It's useful for reduce http request
author: leecade

comments.body: Why are you using ExtractTextPlugin if you want to inline the CSS as part of your JS module?

@sethkinast
I use `System.import` to split files and there is a big entry js, extract `entry.css` is a better way, not sure maybe I can ignore extract css from chunk files

> not sure maybe I can ignore extract css from chunk files

There is an option in the ExtractTextPlugin: `allChunks`, it defaults to `false`. So by default it should ignore css in chunks.
Great @sokra thank you

hi , @leecade , I suffering the react-router code splitting. When I switch different route and just download this route's static file, the js is OK, but the css not work. Can you provide your webpack.config.js or any suggestion to make it ?

title: specified loader not loaded
author: creeperyang

comments.body:
And is there a way to know which loaders are used to handle one file really?

We specify loaders by `test`, and then do these loaders really handle the file when running?


---

@bebraw I wrote a plugin to log out some info, maybe it will help to solve the problem.

``` bash
# compilation.plugin('normal-module-loader'...)   log format: console.log('nml', module.debugId, module.request)

# default will run into success
nml 1001 /MyProj/node_modules/html-webpack-plugin/lib/loader.js!/MyProj/front/viewer/index.html
nml 1002 /MyProj/node_modules/react-dom/index.js
nml 1003 /MyProj/node_modules/react/react.js
nml 1004 /MyProj/node_modules/react-router/lib/index.js
nml 1005 /MyProj/node_modules/babel-loader/index.js?{"presets":["/MyProj/node_modules/babel-preset-es2015/index.js","/MyProj/node_modules/babel-preset-react/index.js","/MyProj/node_modules/babel-preset-stage-0/index.js"]}!/MyProj/front/viewer/app.js
babel-loader loaded------------------- # babel-loader loaded (inject console.log into babel-loader lib)
nml 1006 /MyProj/node_modules/html-webpack-plugin/node_modules/lodash/lodash.js
nml 1007 /MyProj/node_modules/react/lib/ReactDOM.js
...

# Then I move /MyProj/front/viewer --> /tmp/xxx/viewer
# sad, babel-loader even not loaded
nml 1001 /MyProj/node_modules/html-webpack-plugin/lib/loader.js!/private/tmp/xxx/viewer/index.html
nml 1002 /private/tmp/xxx/viewer/app.js # why js file not processed by babel-loader?
nml 1003 /MyProj/node_modules/react-dom/index.js
nml 1004 /MyProj/node_modules/react/react.js
nml 1005 /MyProj/node_modules/react-router/lib/index.js
nml 1006 /MyProj/node_modules/react/lib/ReactDOM.js
nml 1007 /MyProj/node_modules/html-webpack-plugin/node_modules/lodash/lodash.js
nml 1008 /MyProj/node_modules/react/lib/React.js
...
```
It might be that move causing the issues. Try changing `include: [APP_PATH],` to form `include: [APP_PATH, TMP_PATH],` where `TMP_PATH` points to `/private/tmp/xxx/`.

~~I tried but it does not work.~~

It makes sense.

Seems I should write **`/private/tmp` rather than `/tmp`**. Um, maybe it's better to point out the problem about symbol link in document.

Thanks very much.

> Seems I should write /private/tmp rather than /tmp. Um, maybe it's better to point out the problem about symbol link in document.

I don't know how it goes with symlinks. Did you get it to work?

Yes, `babel-loader` is loaded to handle js files.

I should specify `include: ['/private/tmp/xxx/viewer']` instead of  `include: ['/tmp/xxx/viewer']`.
Ok. Safe to close?
Yep. Thanks.

title: webpack2 : remove comments with LoaderOptionsPlugin
body:
Hi there,

Before with the UglifyPlugin, I could pass { comments: false } as options, how to do the same with LoaderOptionsPlugin ?

Thanks
author: Makio64

comments.body: The UglifyPlugin is not affected by the change. LoaderOptionsPlugin is only relevant for loaders that has minimizer includes (i. e. css, html).

Ok, I was thinking LoaderOptionsPlugin replace the UglifyPlugin.
Thanks to clarify.

@sokra is there anything else that tells the affected loaders to use the minimizer option?

for example `NODE_ENV=production` or the `-p` flag

title: Webpack watch doesn't output the new build
body:
Watch recognizes a change in the file and the command line shows it works on a new build, but the file on the file system never gets updated. As soon as I quit the watching process and start it again the correct output is produced. Also running it manually with the following command doesn't give any more insight nor output: ``` webpack --progress --colors --watch --display-error-details --display-chunks --profile ``` ## webpack.config.js ``` js var path = require('path'); module.exports = { devtool : 'source-map', watch: true, context: __dirname + '/App', entry: './index', output: { path: path.join(__dirname, 'wwwroot/dist'), filename: '[name]-bundle.js' }, resolve: { extensions: ['', '.js', '.ts', '.tsx', '.css'], }, module: { loaders: [ { test: /\.tsx?$/, loaders: ['ts-loader']}, { test: /\.css$/, loader: 'style-loader'} ] }, plugins: [] } ``` The file in question is quite simple and I'm only changing text in the paragraph for testing: ## index.tsx ``` import * as React from 'react'; import * as ReactDOM from 'react-dom'; class Dashboard extends React.Component<{}, {}> { render(){ return(

Hello!

); } } ReactDOM.render(, document.getElementById('app')); ``` ## Output ``` webpack --progress --colors --watch --display-error-details --display-chunks --profile 10% 0/1 build modulests-loader: Using typescript@1.8.10 and c:\Development\Enterprise Net2 Manager\Portal\tsconfig.json 1481ms build modules 8ms seal 8ms optimize 10ms hashing 20ms create chunk assets 2ms additional chunk assets 354ms optimize chunk assets 90% optimize assetsemiting 450ms optimize assets 41ms emit Hash: 80d04fe372c49da68b8f Version: webpack 1.13.0 Time: 2404ms Asset Size Chunks Chunk Names main-bundle.js 693 kB 0 [emitted] main main-bundle.js.map 810 kB 0 [emitted] main chunk {0} main-bundle.js, main-bundle.js.map (main) 655 kB [rendered] + 168 hidden modules 204ms build modules 3ms seal 10ms optimize 4ms hashing 9ms create chunk assets 2ms additional chunk assets 382ms optimize chunk assets 90% optimize assetsemiting 372ms optimize assets 39ms emit Hash: 93b94d46db379ef92759 Version: webpack 1.13.0 Time: 1028ms Asset Size Chunks Chunk Names main-bundle.js 693 kB 0 [emitted] main main-bundle.js.map 810 kB 0 [emitted] main chunk {0} main-bundle.js, main-bundle.js.map (main) 655 kB [rendered] + 168 hidden modules ```
author: janpieterz

comments.body: Does this only apply to typescript files or does the same happen with normal js files?
Just spotted that you are using windows. This means `__dirname + "/App"` is an invalid path as windows uses `\` as separator. Better use `path.resolve(__dirname, "App")`.

title: webpack: how to ordering dependencies between entries
author: Trispa

comments.body:
Just put `<script src="lib.js"/>` before `<script src="app.js" />` in your page...
Browser loads scripts in order synchronously. 
It is more complicated when you bundle multiple entries in one file, I noticed it sometimes does mangle the order. The best solution in this case is to just have your main application as an entry, and from there just `require` or `import` your library.
thanks @megakoresh  i did that and it work well now

title: "ERROR in Entry module not found" for module that exists
body:
Bash log: ``` bash ~/code/blockai/merkletree$ npm run gh-pages:build > merkletree@1.4.0 gh-pages:build /Users/olalonde/code/blockai/merkletree > cd demo && rm -rf dist && webpack Hash: 396f0bfb9d565b6f60f0 Version: webpack 1.13.0 Time: 25ms ERROR in Entry module not found: Error: Cannot resolve module 'app.js' in /Users/olalonde/code/blockai/merkletree/demo/src ~/code/blockai/merkletree$ ls /Users/olalonde/code/blockai/merkletree/demo/src app.js ~/code/blockai/merkletree$ cat demo/webpack.config.js module.exports = { context: `${__dirname}/src`, entry: 'app.js', output: { filename: 'bundle.js', path: `${__dirname}/dist`, }, module: { loaders: [ { test: /\.js$/, exclude: /node_modules/, loader: 'babel', query: { presets: ['react', 'es2015'], }, }, ], }, } ~/code/blockai/merkletree$ node --version v6.0.0 ``` The module exists on the filesystem, etc. but webpack says it can't resolve the module. Here's the content of `app.js`: ``` javascript import ReactDOM from 'react-dom' import React from 'react' const App = () => (

hello world!

) ReactDOM.render( , document.getElementById('app') ) ```
author: olalonde

comments.body:
Hmm, replacing

``` javascript
  context: `${__dirname}/src`,
  entry: 'app.js',
```

with 

``` javascript
  // context: `${__dirname}/src/`,
  entry: `${__dirname}/src/app.js`,
```

fixed the error. Maybe I'm misunderstanding the meaning of the `context` option?

``` js
  context: `${__dirname}/src`,
  entry: './app.js',
```

entry is a module request, `app.js` will look for a module named `app.js` in your node_modules

title: Under devServer key in webpack.config.js, I set hot: true option, but it dosen't work
body:
CLI: webpack-dev-server --hot works, 
but

``` js
devServer:{
    hot: true
}
```

it throws Uncaught Error: [HMR] Hot Module Replacement is disabled.
author: Authorlove

comments.body:
If you use `hot: true` that way, I think you need to set

``` javascript
plugins: [
  new webpack.HotModuleReplacementPlugin()
]
```

A little confusing, yeah.

title: [Question]: when will `module` be undefined in UMD webpackBootstrap.
author: pwang2

comments.body: CommonJs 1.0 only specifies the `exports` object. node.js added `module` (CommonJs 1.1.1).
Gotcha, I am still too new to the awesomeness.  Thank you.

title: using commonChunk
author: EasonWang01

comments.body: `'react':require('react'),` -> `'react':require.resolve('react'),`

title: Force re-compile of file from loader
body:
I have file A that requires a file B. When compiling file A I either know about B in advance or I know there might possibly exists file B in future (without knowing its path so I can't use dependency system). When A doesn't know B, it emits error. When I come across valid file B (in loader), I need to recompile A to reflect dependency on discovered B.

Is there a way to force re-compile of A when I discover file B without setting anything in advance? It can even be some internal API that Watcher uses to emit changes. I did go through source code, but wasn't able to find my answer.

Fyi, I'm finishing goog-loader for Google Closure Library with advanced compilation for production. I have a good enough version, but recovery of invalid dependency without editing file A would be nice.

Thank you.
author: aleskafka

comments.body:
Allow me one more question with possible solution. I just need to know some edgy implementation details I could take advantage of.

How does async callback and emitWarning/emitError works? Does emitted warning cancel pending callback or not? Documentation provides no clue about this behaviour.

When I find that A is missing required file B, can I emitWarning and store pending callback for latter when I discover file B?

You could add a context dependency, which is a dependency to a whole directory. Is this enough for your use case?

If not you can flag the file as not cacheable and call `invalidate` on the watcher.

> When I find that A is missing required file B, can I emitWarning and store pending callback for latter when I discover file B?

no. compilation will not finish until callback is invoked.

Thank you. Yes, context dependency could be solution. I'd imagine it could expect glob pattern as argument, but even dirname is fine. I did notice this method exists, but not that it works with directories.

Allow me two follow-up questions.

How does file dependency works? Say I have file A dependent on B and file B dependent on C. Only file C is changed. Which files are recompiled?

How much overhead is there when I addContextDependency for all application files, but in 99% cases callback is provided with cached source from previous compilation (because there wasn't change that would force re-compilation of those files). Is webpack internally optimized when same source is provided to callback? Or is overhead minimum?

Thank you for your time.

> Say I have file A dependent on B and file B dependent on C. Only file C is changed.

It really A' depends on A and B, B' depends on B and C. Where A' and B' are the generated files from A and B. So when C changes only B' is recomplied.

> Is webpack internally optimized when same source is provided to callback?

yes, if it results in the same hash it is not threaded as changed module.

Thank you for your support. I can finalize goog-loader now, thanks to your input. If it stops acting weird on wrong namespace detection (with automatic revival of all files), I will release it for community.

title: I have a question __dirname setting of node config
body:
Hi there.

I'm using express with webpack.
I found __dirname needs set for node and i set like below

```
node: {
  __dirname: false
}
```

Docs comment `__dirname: true` is real __dirname, but Above works. Not `true` (true output '')
Is Docs correct, or not ?

thanks about greate tool!
author: blackpost38

comments.body:
`__dirname: false` disables webpack processing of `__dirname`. If you run the bundle in node.js it falls back to the __dirname of node.js (which makes sense for target: node).
`__dirname: true` let webpack replace `__dirname` with the path relative to you `context`. Makes sense for target: web if you need the path.

I just have the same problem. I think that documentation is very unclear about what it will do:

```
__dirname: true (real dirname), "mock" ("/") or false
```

Great answer thanks!
I wish to apply that comment to docs :)
Yeah, this is confusing. The documentation reads as if the boolean values should have the opposite effect in the resulting bundle.

> __dirname: false disables webpack processing of __dirname. If you run the bundle in node.js it falls back to the __dirname of node.js (**which makes sense for target: node**).

@sokra given what you said above re what makes sense, why is webpack unexpectedly breaking node's behaviour? Shouldn't the node options all be *false* automatically if target is *node*? The mangling of __dirname is counter intuitive and without warning. And in most cases, the output built for node will operate incorrectly rather than failing.

title: Any Way to Reverse the Order of Require.Context?
body:
In my particular use case, I have a folder structure like this:
- angular
  - directives
    - date-range
      - index.js
    - module.js
- module.js

And id like to simply do

``` javascript
require.context('./angular');
```

Right now it seems to include files in the bundle in child first order. So my directives are getting put in the file before the module definitions. Essentially Id like files higher up in the hierarchy to appear before files deeper in the hierarchy.

Is there anyway to do this with require.context?
author: pixelshaded

comments.body:
For this use case, the module files create the modules. The directive files then add directives to those modules. If those modules aren't run and exist before the directive code is run, things won't work right. These aren't commonjs at the moment. I'm really just using webpack process (es6 babel etc) and concat all the files together.

So I started comparing the output for better understanding, and it seems I totally misunderstood what's going on. I haven't gotten to the point yet of testing the bundle on a page and had assumed that the order in which the modules appeared in output was the order they would be executed (aka a pure concat). WRONG. I didn't realize an array of module functions was being passed to the bootstrapper. This is commonjs for front end. Nothing is run until you require a module. All require.context was doing was setting up the modules. So yes, the order of modules passed to the bootstrapper doesn't matter. The order in which you require those modules does, hence your example of re-ordering the keys based on directory depth and then executing them in that new order.

Thanks for taking the time to answer my question.

title: [Plugin] Injecting dependencies based on contents of module
body:
I'm currently struggling to find a way to inject dependencies based on the contents of my module.

I'm using `compiler.parser.plugin` to determine which modules I need to inject dependencies into, but it seems to be too late to inject `require` statements into the source. If I do they're not parsed and converted to the `__webpack_require__` I'm used to seeing.

What is the recommended workflow here?
author: rbhalla

comments.body: write a loader instead.

title: Should webpack build exit error code when a loader fail?
body:
I wrote a very simple async loader, following the documentation step by step, and calling the callback with error when some, **but** webpack just log the error in console and continue, exiting 0 as everything went fine.

Is this an issue or am I missing something?
author: JSteunou

comments.body: This changes with webpack 2 to a non-zero exit code. webpack 1 stays for backward compatiblitity.
Nice, thank you @sokra looking forward for v2 then ;)
With webpack 2, when I deploy to heroku the builds fails and deploy gets rejected because of exit code 2. @sokra is there any way to disable this new feature or force webpack to exit with code 0

title: [Plugin] No events on begin/end of compiling entry points
body:
Hi, 

I'm creating a custom plugin and I need to know the begin/end event of every entry point as I should change the plugin's configuration depending on a specific entry point.

Reading through the docs, I can't find that event.

Thanks,
Jakob
author: jakob101

comments.body:
Can you go a bit into detail?

As in, as far as I understand, you want to change your plugin’s config per-entrypoint, right? If so, then the this-compilation event is what you need. That is used per entry.

I don't know what you try to do, but I'm pretty sure it doesn't work that way.

Instead you should use multiple compilation:

``` js
[
  { entry: "a", plugins: [ new YourPlugin("a") ] },
  { entry: "b", plugins: [ new YourPlugin("b") ] }
]
```
I had only 1 compilation object. This will be helpful. Thank you for your help!

title: How does webpack search path?
author: ibufu

comments.body: @ibufu Can you try `path.join(__dirname, "./static/js/app/src/common/header.js")`? Just a hunch.

title: Use CommonsChunkPlugin twice on one page
body:
As part of our caching strategy, I have set up a configuration where we have two instances of CommonsChunkPlugin: one for vendor scripts; one for common app code. Now we want to include both on every page. But the generated `vendor.js` and `commons.js` each include the webpack runtime, which doesn't work.

Is there a way to remove the runtime from one of those bundles, or is there a different correct way to do this?
author: andrewbranch

comments.body:
I have two instances of CommonsChunkPlugin : vendor and common.
webpack.conf:

```
var entry = {
        profile: [ './app/frontend/javascripts/profile/main.es6'],
        projects: [ './app/frontend/javascripts/projects/main.es6'],
        // the vendor entry point
        vendor: ['babel-polyfill', 'lodash', 'jquery']
    };
```

```
    var plugins = [
        new webpack.optimize.CommonsChunkPlugin("common", 'common' + (options.longTermCaching ? '-[chunkhash].js' : '.js'), ['projects', 'profile']),
        new webpack.optimize.CommonsChunkPlugin("vendor", 'vendor' + (options.longTermCaching ? '-[chunkhash].js' : '.js' ), ['common', 'vendor'], Infinity)
    ];
```

The webpack runtime is only present into the vendor bundle and I can use them like this :

```
  <script src="[...]/assets/vendor.js"></script>
  <script src="[...]/assets/common.js"></script>
  <script src="[...]/assets/profile.js"></script>
```

I hope this will help you (I don't know if it is the correct way to do it but it seems to work)

> Is there a way to remove the runtime from one of those bundles, or is there a different correct way to do this?

@andrewbranch You can do it the way @fredericgrati does it. One of the Plugins should have the name of the other commons chunk in the `chunks` property.
I'm a little confused but that seems to work nicely. Thanks!

title: how to exclude files from loader
author: pavel06081991

comments.body:
What if you had another rule like

``` javascript
{
  test: /\.css$/,
  include: 'someFile',
  loader: 'style!css'
}
```

to deal with that requirement?
What about second rule which I wrote in the privious post, in this case it will not get someFile anymore? only your rule will get this file?
The idea was to write separate rules based on your requirements. You would include/exclude (accepts arrays) based on your exact need.
I understood. Thanks, Juho.
Safe to close?

title: Make TemplatedPathPlugin's replacePathVariables available as a utility.
author: lzilioli

comments.body: Submitted #1649 to address this issue. Feedback welcome, I would love to get this into a release if possible.

You can use it in your plugin.

`TemplatedPathPlugin` is not this thing that does the replacement. It's just a plugin that add some replacements. The actual API is the hook `asset-path` that's usable by everything that has a reference to the mainTemplate (which is in the compilation).

``` js
mainTemplate.applyPluginsWaterfall("asset-path", "some string [hash]", {
    hash: hash,
    chunk: chunk
})
```

If you want to improve something here, add a `getAssetPath(string, options)` function to the `MainTemplate` that calls the hook and replace all occurences. That would look better.

see also #427
cc @diurnalist
@sokra Thanks a lot for the detailed response. This does, in fact meet my needs.

title: is it possible to specify sourceMappingURL?
body:
Hi guys.

Help, please, with the specifying of sourceMappingURL.
We have our own dev-server, so we need to specify sourceMappingURL as a static asset URL like **/dist/bundle.js.map**, but the default output of the webpack is 
**# sourceMappingURL=bundle.js.map**.

Thanks in advance.
author: pkantsedalov

comments.body: You can use the `append` option for the SourceMapDevToolPlugin. i. e. `append: "\n//# sourceMappingURL=/dist/"`

Thanx a lot for the response.

The final result is the next one: 

```
new webpack.SourceMapDevToolPlugin({
    filename: '[file].map',
    append: `\n//# sourceMappingURL=${path}[url]`
})
```
